urlLink CNN.com : "Cassini races toward Saturn orbit Cassini races toward Saturn orbit Cassini will shoot through a gap in Saturn's rings on Wednesday night and become the first spacecraft ever to orbit the giant planet about 930 million miles away from Earth. 'Everything appears to be right on track,' said Robert Mitchell, Cassini program manager, at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California. Cassini has spent seven years making a 2.2 billion-mile journey to study Saturn's atmosphere, magnetic field and weather." Isn't today June 30th? Isn't something supposed to happen in Iraq today? And this is the headline on CNN.com? Does anyone else notice something is wrong? WE ARE SUPPOSED TO HAND OVER POWER TO THE IRAQI PEOPLE TODAY. Not that the average american cares, it doesn't have to do with their stock portfolio, or the price of gasoline, or how good life in the US is. I'm watching CNN Headline News now, and one of the stories in the first half hour--the time deddicated to real news that affects the world and the country--is SPORTS. Sports matters SO much more than world news. The latest football scores are more important than the Lacy Peterson trial. Typical American... Knowing all the stats of the 1985 Super Bowl than how to do basic algebra. Wonder why we're so behind in the technological world?

Myst last couple of posts have been responses to news and the like (genetic super baby isn't quite news, but eh..) and I think that's how I'm going to update most thigns. My life is pretty damn boring, but I love the news and satire, so I think that I'm going to just keep doing that..."reflect" on the news. If something interesting happens to me though, I'll post it in here. Like today, Don and I went to Presq Isle and went wandering around at black rocks. It was a hell of a lot of fun. We discovered this pretty neat vertical shaft, that's just cut in the cliff. We were looking in this part of the rock that was a crack, and it looked like it opened up in the back, and we could see light. So we climbed to the top and looked down, it was really cool. It's really neat how formations like that are created in cliffs. I'll post pictures once I take some.

Ok, seriously. What the fuck is so awesome about Counter-Strike? I'm at a LAN party, and it's all we've been playing for the past few hours. Sure, CS was fun 5 or so years ago when it came out, but there's sooo much better online multiplayer shooters out now! Unreal Tournament 2004 or whatever. I'v read nothing but good things about it. Or Halo for the PC. The online multiplayer is just plain awesome. But, all anyone want's to play is: Counter-Strike. Oh, and don't even think about telling someone that CS is boring now, because they'll get all offended and mad and challenge you even though you know all they do is sit in their parent's basement playing CS. Or telling them that 'all we ever play here is counter-strike' because that will usually get the response of 'No we don't, we play other games.' Sure, granted that other games are played here, but, for the most part, guess what game is played. Counter-Strike. I think people need to play some of the other, better, slightly newer shooters out there. It's really boring playing aginst three or four people who do nothing but play this game. All the other people here (except Max, go Max!*) are playing CS, and either getting pissed because they died once, or yelling and laughing much too loudly because they killed someone. Let's play some Battlefield 1942 or something! REALLY people, get out and play some better online shooters. -Tom, not playing CS. *Max is playing Diablo II, an awesome game.

Life is boring, really. In today's world, all of us are forced to conform all through school, that we usually end up getting rushed into college (or the military) and jobs that we really aren't ready for yet. We are told to "Sit down and shut up, we're learning about WWII agian" all through school that we forget what really makes us individual: asking questions. Sure, we can ask questions like, "Who was the man at Stalingrad?" But if we ask the important questions like, "Did the man at Stalingrad enjoy looking at rainbows?" we are told to stop asking such silly questions, that we are more adult than that. But the thing is, if the important questions are drilled out of us so soon, are not each and every one of us the same? Every time we are told to be quiet, a small part of us dies. Never stop asking the important question: "Do you know what it feels like to be happy?"

urlLink Slashdot: News for nerds, stuff that matters : "Auto Manufacturers Running Out Of Unique IDs Technology/IT Posted by timothy on Thursday July 01, @04:27PM from the hence-the-stupid-car-names dept. wakebrdr writes 'Y2K all over again? A story in today's Detroit News explains how the vehicle ID numbering system (VIN) will soon run out of unique numbers. According to the article, a member of the Society of Automotive Engineers says, 'Longer codes would require a major overhaul of computer systems that would dwarf the challenges and expenses spawned by the Y2K computer dilemma.' Golly, if it's that serious maybe I should start stocking up on MREs and ammunition in preparation for the day the assembly lines come to a screeching halt.'" Everything is finite, and I guess it's finally showing. Maybe if there's no more numbers, they'll stop making new SUV's which no one needs! That's a fat chance, but I can hope. I think that we can use this to our advantage, comparing the finite number if VIN's to the finite amount of oil avaliable. I'm guessing that by...I'll say 2016 for good measure, that the earth will be out of oil, unless we do some SERIOUS rethinking on how we use it. Think of it: a LOT of people today drive SUV's, which most of them don't need. Almost everything you use has plastics in it. You're probally reading this on a monitor encased in plastic, using a mouse made of plastics for navigation, and plinking away on a keyboard made of: you guessed it! Plastic! The basic structure for plastic comes from oil, so that means that you better go easy on that keyboard! You never know when you can't afford a cheap one anymore!
